"Why Can’t We Make New Stradivari Violins? Actually, we can. Stradivarius are no better than the best hand-crafted violins made today. Strads are definitely better than machine-made violins and custom violins, but they are not better than hand-crafted violins from the best lutiers today. The reason why the sound of a Strad sounds so much more polished and richer than that of even the best hand-made violins today is mostly due totwo things:
1. The polish - We don't know exactly what varnish Stradivarius used, but the varnish that he used was specific to Cremona at the time, and had a mix of minerals and oils that gave the wood great density and ressonance ability but without creating echo. While it is impossible to replicate the exact varnishes that Stradivarius used, we can replicate varnishes that give the wood a density and ressonance ability similar to a Strad byu analysing the density and sound vibrancy of the wood.
2. Time - Like wine, violins get better with time as the wood becomes less and less echoey which allows it to vibrate sounds more clearly.
If you were to get the absolute top-of-the-line hand-crafted violins from some of the best lutiers from France and Italy today, and give it a varnish similar to the ones used in Cremona at the time, you would basically have a brand-new Stradivarius. The problem is, you would still need to wait 200 years for it tio truly sound like a Strad. Even 100 years is too short a time for that. We can replicate perfectly the artisinal craftsmanship of a Stradivarius, and we can replicate well although nor perfectly the varnishing. What we cannot replicate, though, is the effect of the passage of time. So yes, we cannot have new Strads now .

all violins made in northern italy were treated with chlorine, boron, sulphur mixture to preserve the wood. It was figured out by a violin maker/geologist in the 80s or 90s when he discovered that none of the violins from that region had any damage from woodworms. So his conclusion was they were treated and he was correct.  They took actual shavings of repaired Strad's into a lab and tested them under microprobe and figured it out.  The collectors all got mad and ganged up on him so their research is not that well known about because the Strad collector community cannot accept the fact the mystery is solved. It's true, there is a little documentary on here about this.

The wood on playing instruments should be examined in cross section using micro CT-scanning. On some fragments examined by Gary Baese, the wood on the. tables was apparently carved thicker and then mechanically compressed by burnishing on both sides with the grain, using a mold for support. The compression to half the original thickness doubles the density and does nothing to compromise the longitudinal structure of the tables. It makes the wood more vibratory. Then for varnish, the makers simply used what was available locally for furniture varnish. Amazingly, the company making amber/linseed oil varnish used in the inner coats was still in business in the 1970s when Gary did his research, and may still be. And they still made this varnish which has a property of self-healing should it be scratched.

There is 100% a difference between Strads and other violins. Most people when listening to music couldn't tell you much about the instruments making the music but many musicians could take very educated guesses or practically know which types of instruments are being used. For example, different models of guitars from different manufacturers are GENERALLY known to have particular characteristic sounds, same with the bass. Often musicians will become so familiar with specific types of instruments that they can identify it without looking, just like someone who works on cars might be able to recognize a vehicle by its start up and idle sound. I am a lifelong musician but have NO training and almost no knowledge of violins but I've listened to comparisons of Strads, Guarneri's and a few "lesser" violins and 10 out of 10 times I identified the super-valuabled violins by using my ear and listening closely. The value of these pieces is going to be subjective but the age, history and quality of the sound is a testament to them being works of art, just like many paintings or sculptures. It may be arguable the value of these kinds of things but they hold an elusive quality of being nearly unreplicatable, just like famous works of art, and I think the stories act as inspiration and romanticize the process of developing and crafting an instrument. They are valuable because they are a benchmark and while modern builders MAY have matched Stradivarius and Guarneri, they haven't yet surpassed them.

The ability to discern extremely fine distinctions is something people have in varying degrees. It's partly physiological and partly training. I know someone with extremely acute color sensitivity. This person can (for example) not only match fabrics dyed from the same dye vs other dye lots, they can match fabrics within a specific dye lot. I've tested this individual's color matching ability using the finest distinctions possible with 24-bit color, at it is indeed pretty exceptional. In tests, no one else I've found (including professional artists), can match it.

The same goes for taste, hearing, and touch. So unless an extremely high standard set and bench-marked, these blind test are meaningless. If perhaps only one person in 1,000 can reliably tell a Strad from another violin, or 1 in 10,000, or 1 in 10 million, it doesn't mean the difference is not there. It simply means that only that person can discern it.

As for the psychological effect, this is also can also be misunderstood. Our brains can be trained to recognize fine distinctions, but they don't always. It takes effort and motivation -- the brain needs to be "primed" to do the work, to focus and concentrate, to detect these fine distinctions. Otherwise, they'll be missed. Telling a person "you're playing/listening to" a Strad could be just such a clue.

Finally, the whole "these 2 things are exactly the same" -- no. No 2 things are exactly the same. There are always differences. They exist at gradations varying from course, to extremely fine, down to the molecular and to atomic level. What is the limit of discernment? Under the proper conditions, the naked human eye (some exceptional human eyes, that is) can detect as few as 2 photons -- possibly even one. It's quite remarkable -- and not easy to achieve. So whether it's violins or cigarettes, the powers of human perception often exceed the ability of people setting up tests to determine the degree of similarity between the things being tested, and the testing method can be based on unfounded assumptions. All of this must be considered before concluding two things are "the same" or not.

For the record, I have a tin ear. I couldn't tell a Strad from a bust chainsaw. (Well, maybe I could? Barely.) But that doesn't mean no one else can.

Part of the difference in Strands and modern violins is the finish. Stradivarius used a finish made from turps and bee propolis, bees wax, thickened tree sap, etc. Virtually all modern finishes are petroleum based resins and varnishes, etc. The different finishes cause the woods to vibrate slightly differently.

We could, and by "we" I mean the finest luthiers in the world, make a new, accurate and so fine-sounding Strad as long as "we" had on hand exactly the same materials as were used to make the original ones.
Of course, that is as impossible as paining with Rembrandt's paints. None of the original materials exist anymore and replicas of these materials, no matter how attentive and finely crafted, would not be accurate to the original materials as many if not all of the ingredients that went into making them also no longer exist, and so on, etc. Also, the exact ratio of these ingredients, colour by colour, is unknown. Great age has deeply affected what we observe or can measure on his canvases today.
This so for Strads. They surely sound and feel quite different today, and would do so even if they were played over the ages by the same musicians, which is, of course, impossible, than how they sounded when they were made, which is yet another thing that we cannot know.
Even the piss that was so famously, fortuitously and randomly sprayed upon the wood piled on the dock, which wood was used to make Strads, had chemical compositions that are unknown and therefore unreplicable, not mention that of the wood itself.
Making a great Strad-quality violin is just like creating a great lawn. First, you get the very best grass seed available and find a relatively flat field covered with thick, rich planting soil. This field must be in a place such that it has the best ratio of hot, moderate and cool weather, as well as the perfect quantity of rain fall throughout the year. Then you sow the exactly correct amount of the seed per square foot. Finally, you fertilize it, mow it, and weed it for five hundred years. No problem.

Stradivari Violins are not the BEST sounding violins. They just have a sound. That sound is bright, with highs for cutting in a large hall. Stradivari and Guarnei both learned from another violin maker called Amati. Amati's violins sounded great, but were not very loud. I mean, not very loud at all, as in you could maybe hear it well in a reflective bathroom. So, this is where Stradivari and Guarnei learned their crafts.

Stradivari Violins were made for playing large halls AND having the people in the far seats be able to hear them. Stradivari Violins don't actually sound as good a del Gesu/Guarneri violin which is best in chamber music.... in smaller rooms. They have better low tones than a Strad. A Stradivari in a small live chamber can make your ears and eyes bleed. The del Gesu in the same chamber (20' x 20' x 20') will warm your heart. The del Gesu violins have a dark (deep warm) sound. These rooms or halls are part of the instrument, actually. The instruments are DRIVERS for the hall or chamber. An old friend of mine, now dead, turned sheet music for Heifetz when he came through town in the Midwest. He said Heifetz sounded like ripping and not good up where he was. However, Heifetz's playing that night as it went into the hall sounded great. You see, the violin is part of the room at that point.

The prices of these either of these violins is based on their collectors value, not the sound. They are investments, like paintings or stocks. Heifetz had one of each in the 1940s. You can see them on films that were made of him back stage from then. The face of must violins are made of spruce. There is a stage where the face is tuned. That means that wood is removed (bottom or top, but mostly bottom) to reach a pitch when tapped on. You know, tap tap tap. This will cause the face, all by itself with out being attached to the rest of the violin, to resonate at a pitch. As in F5 mandolins this pitch is important to the tone. They don't use sandpaper or CNC machines to do this. Just to confuse the readers, the bow makes more difference in the sound that the violin. Things like the weight, the action, etc... all make a big difference. However, if you have the right bow, with the right hair, and the right strings, with the right rosin, and then a player like Heifetz, then violin can be the important part of the combo. The violinist's technique makes all the difference here. You can see where violin makers were trying to address specific performance conditions back then.

Hey Guy, I have studied Strads and Guarneri instruments. I even purchased CAT scans and diagrams with tiny details of these instruments, through The Library of Congress. Most of what you have said is accurate but I detect 3 mistakes or omissions. 1. mentor and teacher. Stradivari had been Guarneri's apprentice. They were neighbors and had houses and workshops a few hundred feet apart on adjacent streets. 2. Stradivari used several different woods because good wood was expensive. At first at least, he most often used wood from the ocean. He would search for sunken ships and broken boat oars, because the wood was very good and free. Later in life as he and his sons became more prosperous their primary wood of choice was Norway Spruce, for the front and back. Maple on the side. Ebony or rosewood on the neck. 3. The "special process" chemists talk about may have been as simple as getting salty driftwood from the ocean and nothing more. But, thank you for this excellent piece. BTW, experts seldom agree about anything, especially Strads. So take what I say with a glass of old saltwater.

What the " Strad " question always ignores are the gazillion factors which affect the quality of the sound produced by any violin at any given time. The skill of the player, the quality and manner of construction of the strings, the bridge/sound post set up, the amount of resin on the bow, the manner of bowing, air humidity, local acoustics, and probably the most important of all - the quality of the Mark 1 ear listening to the sound. If a Strad can consistently produce good sound against all these odds then it has some transcendental quality. If it cannot, then is doesn't.

Several things in the guitar world that could make a difference in violins also, though I think the deal with strads is likely mythology...

1) While it is hard to get good wood at lumber yards, the quality of what you can get from specialty shops is amazing. Modern guitars often have this incredible wood with 64 rings and inch, and expertly sawn. Some of the old 19th century guitars use stuff you could have got in a 1970s 2x4. The better wood is tighter, stiffer, definetly what you want in an airplane wing, but not necessarily is a vibratory surface,

2) Modern makers often finish everything as though it was a piece of furniture for the finest salon. This can include very finely finished inner surfaces where the air volume is (not coated, just super smoothed). It has been suggested that this pumps air less efficiently. Seems unlikely, but it is at least a thing.

3) There is some evidence that playing instruments makes them more responsive, so centuries of playing by great violinists might loosen the violin up. I had a guitar that when played fingerstyle, sounded a lot better when you strummed it violently for a while, first. It was really noticeable. It was a peculiar guitar, with only two braces and a stiffer top. There are, or were devices that vibrate instruments on purpose like this. With my guitar, you had to loosen it every time. It did not create a permanent effect. No idea if this is a real thing.

I have been in the string instrument business for almost 40 years. No two instruments sound the same but it takes years of playing old instruments to really understand them. A Brazilian Rosewood guitar from the 1930s is by far the best sounding string instrument ever made but that's not a fair comparison to make. A violin goes through many alterations over 400 years. Almost none have the original necks because music changed and they needed to be able to hit higher notes. The tops sometimes get scraped down making them thinner. Repairs are not always done properly. Some wood came from Bosnia which was floated behind a ship so it sat in salt water for months sometimes. That would introduce the minerals they find in the wood. This argument will go on forever but no one will ever say a Strad is not the most amazing Violin ever made. The highest price ever paid for one is $15 Million but a Giuseppe "del Gesù" Guarneri sold for 16 million. A Strad Viola was on the market for $45 million but no takers yet. Guarneri did not make as many Violins as Stradivari who made about 1100. That makes them very rare.

The theory that WELL made modern day instruments can POTENTIALLY outperform centuries old string instruments makes PERFECT SENSE . Making a GREAT sounding violin, viola or cello is difficult and definitely a genuine art left to truly artistic craftspeople but it's not voodoo science and well within the realm of possibility. AND there is another incalculable element or variable: taste. What people HEAR and like, can't help but influence their "best sound" choice.  
AND guess what? The world of STRING CHOICES for instruments is not subject to full objectivity either. On a cello, for instance, two variables are wholly responsible for a cellist's choice of strings. The cello itself might respond better to one string vs another . . . according player A. To player B on the SAME cello AND with the SAME strings, it might not "perform" well. So now you have the INSTRUMENT itself adding a variable for each individual player, leaving the choice of strings aside. This adds a real complication to ANY blind testing . . . a 300 year old Strad might not "like" Eva Pirazzi Gold strings while a modern one could "love" them. While strings can make an indelible impression on an instrument's sound and a listener's inevitable bias adds another, you have this infinite loop of possible variables that can influence the outcome of any test. In the final analysis, ALL that REALLY COUNTS is if an instrument is pleasing to listen to whether it's one year old or 3 hundred years old.This comparison stuff is pretty well useless unless your comparing entry level instruments to professional level instruments and even THEN lower cost instruments can play WELL above their "pay grade" : )

Perhaps it is worth noting that not all of Stradivari's violins were made to the same pattern. His earliest ones very much followed the Amati pattern, as it was Andreas Amati who invented the instrument and to whom Stradivari was an apprentice. His mid-period instruments had some what larger bodies while his late period instruments were back to a smaller size again but with not such a deep curve on the plates. Thus said, all the known violins do seem to have a 'house sound' which is different from either the Guaneri or Amati (Nicolo) violins which were also made in Cremona at around the same time period and from very similar timber. Having heard all three in a demonstration there is quite a difference. The sound of the Amati can be described as 'deeper', 'richer' and 'darker' than the others. Guaneri are known for being 'powerful' and 'penetrating', some players select them for this feature. Stradivari are often considered to have the best balance, with words like 'silken', 'silvery', 'crystal clear' and 'expressive' being used to describe their sound. Just as any good modern luthier can engineer a guitar to produce a sound of a particular character, so it seems that the violin makers in Cremona could do the same with their violins. One can imagine that 'back in the day' a violin player might have selected which maker to purchase his instrument from based upon how he wanted it to play and sound. The Carpathian Spruce and European Sycamore (not Maple, but a related species) with which those violin makers started would have been selected from the same supply.

I can tell you exactly why they will never make another violin sound like a Stradivari. When Antonio Stradivari was alive and making violins during the 17tth century, he lived during a time that is known as the Little Ice Age, a regional cooling that occurred in Europe and thought to have been brought from heightened volcanic activity, especially from a catastrophic eruption of Mount Tawarewa in New Zealand in 1315 and lasted for several hundred years on and off until the 19th century. The colder climate made the wood Stradivari used to become more dense then during the periods of warmer climate and contributed to the unique tone of his instruments. We may have access to the same materials he had, but not the same climate conditions.

I’ve been lucky enough to know someone who May have figured out the secret. (It is just a hypotheses technically but it’s a very well educated one):
Back in that day, there was a bug that lived and ate many of the woods of that time. The luthier I know thinks that he treated his wood with very harsh acidic chemicals in a copper tub as to prevent any bugs from eating away the wood in his instruments. The acid opened up pours in the wood allowing it to have a “softer, silvery sound” but have a more flat shape than the violins before him. Flat shapes generally have less softness but more volume. His had the flatness for volume but the porous wood to have the softer tone, being exactly what every violinist wants. No sacrifice for volume of tone, but both. You can vary the shape of the violin to adjust how soft the tone is and how loud it is. But, with wood like that, especially the more dense wood from post ice age, no matter the shape, the violin will sound better than another violin of the same volume or tone. Because it will be louder than a violin with a similar tone, and sound better than a violin with a similar volume.

His microscope analysis of a Stradivari showed the wood was more porous than other violins of similar age as well.

But him being a secretive luthier himself, he never published the information he found, as he is now trying to make his own technique to replicate it. He may not have access to that same wood, but he can try and treat the wood we have today the same way as Strad treated his wood before making the violin.

I was freshly home from Navy deployment when a friend showed up with a heart-broken look in his face. It was 2AM and he NEVER acted like that. He was an Army Ranger, in for holiday leave as well, and so I invited him in. I knew something was wrong. He carried a familiar, ratty looking guitar case and laid it on the kitchen table. Without a word he opened it and I knew what I would see, but my heart sank when the damage was visible.
It was a guitar his father had made in 'Nam, the old man's second tour. He'd improvised his own jigs, bartered wherever he could for materials, and glue, and slowly fashioned probably the lightest guitar I'd ever held in my hands, before or since. Apparently, on his trip home, the airport staff had dropped the case, and the impact had sprung about a third of the seam between the top and side around from next to the pick-guard around past the tail-piece.

The old man had died while my friend was on his first tour of duty, and this was especially hard for him to deal with... I was the only person he knew who remotely resembled a lutier... SO I nodded and offered a brave smile... and still without a syllable, he retreated to the door and out. He was never one to let anyone see him cry.

It took a week, but very VERY carefully I steamed and prayed, inching my way around to fully expose the joint and extract the neck of the thing. I took off the tail-piece and simply enough, sacrificed the strings. They weren't important. They get used up, and for about 5 bucks, I could easily replace them. Every creek or murmur of the wood and my nerves were rattled, I'd cringe or wince so hard I could practically taste my own testicles! BUT finally, the top rose away and I was able to gaze at a delicacy of carving and shaping I could scarcely fathom... Next I examined every inch. There were a few stressed cracks, but some super-glue or urethane was dabbled into them deeply with X-Acto's and a biological probe, I'd found in a microscope kit years before... AND careful weighing down or clamping kept the thing from curling out of place while the glue finished curing... I scraped and scraped and then snapped off the end of a square file to scrub through grooves to get rid of the old glue, and finally cleaned it all before adding fresh, modern adhesive and then pressing the guitar carefully back together... I went ahead and rode down to a store in town for a new set of strings... and a set of AA batteries for my old digital tuner... A new piece of leather was needed for the neck, firming the fitting properly before I could remove the last of old wires and immediately replace them with fresh... AND it was nicely tuned when Nate came around to check up on my progress...

AND his joy at seeing his Daddy's old guitar not only back in one piece but to pick it up and play it again... THAT was a moment I will never forget. Not only had I been truly privileged with the trust of a beloved instrument, the last piece of his father's heart, soul, and memory embodied in something hand made by the old man, but I'd accomplished what I was trusted to do. Two boys had left their home town for different ends of the world, during our own war-time services... We'd become men and done a LOT of growing up for that.

...BUT for that beloved guitar, hand crafted in a hell-hole like Vietnam by the grizzled hands of a Marine who'd be hated when he returned... We were boys again... if for a short time. We could sing and dance as if we were rock-stars, and the old man was right there in our hearts and memories... dancing and laughing with us...

It was GLORIOUS. It was the single MOST BEAUTIFUL sounding instrument I'd ever heard in my life... and will likely remain so. ;o)

The comment about his name being “latinized” is sort of misleading. “Stradivari” and “Stradivarius” both come from latin. It’s just that when referring to someone directly who has a name ending in “ius”, latin grammatical rules change it to a long “i”. So technically both names are correct, one form has just become more popular because latin grammatical rules are not really followed.

You've missed the key difference. The sound post is offset. Strad violins therefore have asymetrical thicknesses to the back and areas between the f-holes. You can drastically improve the sound of a $100 violin by scraping the inside of the instrument, making it sound like a $1,000 instrument. Copies of Strads made in the last 300 years have symetrical wood thicknesses, so the wood doesn't vibrate uniformly across the wood plane with an offset sound post.

It's a Scam. I'll give you an example that kind of applies to the Strads. The Diamond company De Beers was soo good at finding and mining Diamonds, that they had soo much of it on hand. If they released them all as they found them, Diamonds would be much more common and therefore less valuable, the value of Diamonds would plummet and it would crash the Diamond Market. So what they decided to do was only release a fraction of what they had on hand at any given time, keeping the market limited and thereby actively managing the market, and keeping the prices high. The same could be said for the Strad. There are only soo many Strads left, that alone keeps the market prices high. I'm no expert on stringed instruments, but I can tell you that all musical instruments of the past were more mellow and less brilliant than those today. They would have found today's musical instruments shrill. If, in the test you mentioned, the participants preferred the modern instrument, the explanation is probably that they are accustomed to the greater brilliance of modern musical instruments. Perhaps they even found the strad dull by comparison.

After one gets used to listening to 16th-18th century music on "period instruments", one tends to be annoyed by the strident sound of the modern instruments. I know that I got to a point where I found the sound of modern instruments ugly and only listened to recordings played on "period instruments".

The experiment didn't prove anything. Stards by nature of their age take more time for the player to play them correctly in order to make them resonate probably, and avoid some dead spots that might have happened over time if the violin wasn't treated correctly. A newer violin is usually more straight forward, will have less defects but also less potential, and therefore on a blind test the violinist will be able to play better than on a violin that take more time to get to know. So basically the experiment was BS.
Also, I would imagine it's very possible to just test what overtones does a world class violinist produce on either instrument. Weird it wasn't done or brought up.

The problem with Strad blind tests (like wine tasting blind tests) the sample is flawed and also human memory isn’t reliable. What these tests can tell us is, after pass a certain point for the majority of people the small incremental of quality doesn’t matter. However if you have someone that plays a Strad almost on a daily basis I.e Ray Chen (or in the case of wine, you have Masters of Wine and Master Sommeliers doing the wine tastings) the likelihood of these research being inconclusive is highly unlikely. In the case of wine things are even more complex because some wines are expensive due to supply and demand. On average, if you use the most expensive methods of making wines and you are able to make a good quality wine at a reasonable volume (the annual volume of lafite) you are looking at approx $80 a bottle to cover your costs and make some profit. So from a quality standpoint, a medium size no name winery could theoretically produce a bottle of wine that rivals a lafite but is significantly cheaper. This makes the whole concept of having someone blind test to guess price based on quality to be more flawed, since you can’t taste spike in price caused by demand. The same could be said for Strads in the sense that modern violin is cheaper and people can’t tell the difference between it and the Strad doesn’t devalue the Strad, it just means there are more supply of the modern violin than the Strad and in fact it shows the Strad is amazing to sound on par if not better than modern violins with ancient violin making methods.

Tossing all the gibberish and mythology(urine, blood of virgins, etc), some things may actually make a difference - like the wood, when trees grew under different conditions that may have created finer grain, consistent resin, etc. A few contemporaries also made legendary instruments, so that may have been an understood aspect. But when you consider how their reputation really took off more than a century after his death, that belies the idea that he had control of aging processes, how varnishes were going to mature and season perfectly, when he had no way of testing in his lifetime. Some modern instruments may produce quality sound, but are they as playable from the musician's perspective? If so, will they stay consistent after twenty, fifty, a hundred years and beyond? Musicality is a synergy of instrument and player, whose ears are likely more sensitive than all but the most discerning critic. Distinguishing one instrument from another is the first step in assessing them; sonic preferences alone, like wine, may be a matter of subjective taste, but with a violin at least the player can say if it is responsive to their intentions.

The lumber used was unique.
Buried lumber left in mud underwater, the logs were then harvested and dried out.
There were only so many of these logs found and therefore, the materials were used up.
Lignin in the wood was "eaten" up by the bacteria at a much slower rate than would be on dry land.
This left the lumber with a unique characteristic in it's sound.

First, the wood used in modern instruments is the wrong wood. The wood used in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries was from naturally grown forests with relatively dense growth. The density of growth meant slower development of the trees and narrower annual ring growth. Narrower rings meant denser, harder wood. Today's wood is from managed forests with a much lower density of growth permitting greater annual growth ring, hence less dense, lighter wood. The sound transmission through the differing woods necessarily results in a different sound from the instrument. Second, there are differences in both the glues and the varnishes used, which may or may not have a material effect on the sound.

The biotech version of the wood sounds sketchy as described.  Tighter ice age wood would be stiffer, so why getting non ice age wood and eating some of it away would make it like Strad wood is far from clear.  In any case there is tremendous variance of modulus of elasticity in bits taken from the same board.  This is hugely evident with arrows, where only 20 percent of the arrows sawn from a piece of wood will typically fall into a stiffness set.  The rest will be one or two sets either side.  We know this because every piece of wood is graded for stiffness and weight in arrow making.  When you cull for weight you won't even get 20% in the same set.  So there is so much variance in the wood you can't even compare two tops from the same board.  This is where the luthier's technique comes into play where he has to get each instrument sounding as he wants it to regardless of the starting point.  This is called "voicing".

I believe a version of your final conclusion, though it begs as to why the myth attached itself to Strads.

The other issue about Strads is they were baroque violins designed to be played with early strings and bows, and originally had longer necks that suited that set-up. So at this point many parts have had to be replaced to create the modern instrument, and to deal with wear of parts like the bridge. And general repairs have been ongoing for centuries. So it is a little hard to understand whatever difference exists as entirely intentional.

The answer to this is EASY!!! Yeah, you can analyze the carve patterns, structure, glue, finish, use the same maple, spruce, and ebony, and accurately clone a Stradivarius, but it won't sound like one, though it might sound very good. There is ONE reason, and one reason only...... TIME!!! Let that instrument age and be played for 300+ years, and you'll have a better shot at hearing a very similar instrument.

TIME!!! It's the one thing that science has yet to conquer. In this case, you can't reproduce that aging through artificial means. I speak this truth as a musical instrument repairman and builder. The musical instrument industry has been trying to do this for years with OTHER instruments.

Interesting, but you didn't say a word about the glue and varnish Stradivari used. Back then, modern curing and drying agents had not been developed. A violin builder like Stradivari would have had a special drying room, where parts of violins would be hung, sometimes for months or years. It was a slow process to make these instruments and required a lot of patience. The long curing and drying time would not be commercially feasible today, but it may have produced a higher quality in sound and in durability of the instruments.

I've NEVER heard these referred to as "Strads". I HAVE heard of STRATS - this is a shortened version of the FENDER STRATOCASTER which is a guitar. But all that aside there is no magic formula or diatoms or little micro organisms or metals or any type of VOODOO and are not the answer either. Sadly TIME is the ultimate factor in it as this makes the wood harder. Some other factors are area where it was produced in its' climate and what type of glue was used. They didn't have Elmers glue or other modern day adhesives. Mostly they used TREE SAP for it and the finishes were made from the same sandaric resins as available today. Only we now refer to violin finishes as varnish. Also another thing to consider is that they used cat gut or goat innards for the strings. This too produced a different sound.

A new violin would produce the same basic sound and resonance. However all the technical mumbo - jumbo aside the Stradivarius sounds just like any other violin that I've heard. It's mostly the snob appeal of owning something so old and made in a time that has long passed that is of the most interest. The Guarnerius violins sound just as good and metals would be absorbed into the earth into any living plant so immersing them in a metallic solution is preposterous! Also there is a blind test video (on YouTube) where no one knew what violin that they were playing and most of the people didn't even know the difference between the three - Stradivarius, Guarnerius, or the modern ones. Showing that this all mainly boils down to snob appeal! I could tell very slight variances but it was so minute that it didn't make a damned bit of difference! Thanks for playing along......

Musicians are the biggest snobs.

I bought a 120 dollar nickel plated trumpet off ebay (A Cecilio) and it sounded so good that I got compliments and questions about the brand all the time, but to be frank, musicians are just fragile.

I was playing first chair trumpet in college with people who played trumpets that were literally 40x+ the price of mine. Not only does it suck to be outranked by another player... but add onto it that that player is playing on an instrument a fraction of what yours cost? Yes... musicians get defensive.

These days, I'm a guitar guy... and the pickup market is RIDICULOUS! I mean, sure... they make a difference, but to say one functional pair of pickups is better than another... that's snobbery. I could pay hundreds of dollars for vintage humbuckers, but really... at the end of the day, I find single-coil pickups to have better dynamic range and articulation (but they do have a higher noise-floor)

They try to reinvent single-coils by making rails or lipstick humbuckers (and get rid of the noise-floor), but none of these are better to my ear than regular single-coils. There is ALWAYS a sacrifice of dynamics and articulation on the other end when bucking noise... and what's more, single-coils are EXCEPTIONALLY easy to make. I'll stick with a set of single coils and a good noise-gate.

The thing about instruments these days is... you can have 95% of what you want for 100 bucks... or you can have 99% of what you want for a LITERALLY INFINITE AMOUNT OF MONEY (but you will ALWAYS find something else to want).

At some point, you have to tap to the fact that it's subjective and personal what instrument you want to play... and you have to just adopt one and start making music. Before you know it, the other instruments won't sound right to you.

Because the man himself is gone, of course; that's the obvious answer. But it is definitely possible to make equally good sounding instruments if you know the craft, have a perfect ear for music, and know "the secret". The "secret" is simply the mating of the two halves of the violin - or any instrument in the same category, the top and the bottom; they have to sound in perfect harmony. If they don't, they will work against one another and will never make up a perfect musical instrument. It may be good, but it will not be great. So, in order to mate those two in the best possible way, you'd need a very good ear. Stradivari evidently had a great ear for music; and in his workshop, as it was found after his death, were a lot of instrument tops and bottoms hanging alongside the walls, just waiting for their perfect partner. I believe he never compromised on this. That's his secret, and that's all, really.

So called blind comparisons miss the point of how the instrument responds to the player while they're playing it. While an audience may not be able to reliably tell the difference, the musician is more easily able to produce the sounds they desire with particular instruments. Also, a gifted instrument maker is able to compensate for the natural variation in materials to 'tune' the end result. That intuitive sense is not easily reproduced.
There is an electric guitar amplifier made by a fellow named Alexander Dumble. He only made around 200 of them, primarily for various studio musicians in the '80s like Larry Carlton or Robben Ford. Each was individually tuned by the maker to compensate for variations in electronic components, and to complement the technique and desires of the musician it was made for. These are now around $125,000 on the used market. Mainly ending up with well healed collectors and some successful musicians like Carlos Santana or John Mayer. Like the Stradivari, people have been able to somewhat reverse engineer them and blind comparisons are difficult to distinguish. But those who have played them (I count myself as fortunate) know that the ability to produce tones through them has not been perfectly replicated.

This is in the same category as organists who prefer tracker action organs (tracker action organs have an entirely mechanical connection between the key and the pallet- the valve that lets wind into the pipes). They claim thay can get a desirable sound because they can control how fast the pallet opens when pressing the keys. This is actually challenging because the key press force on a tracker action organ is initially high because they are working against the wind pressure on the closed pallet. But once open, the pressure goes away and the key falls quickly. Electric-ediated actions or electronic organs don't have this inital pressure on their key presses. In any case, they did a kind of double blind test with tracker and electronic instruments modified to have a tracker touch on their keys. Listeners thoroughy familiar with organ music could not tell any difference that could be related to touch.

There are a few errors here. First, Antonio Stradivari didn't make all of these instruments by himself. It was a family business that his sons helped in and continued after his death. During his life it is thought they made about 1150 instruments total of all types. Second, there aren't 650 Stradivari violins still in play. That is the approximate number of Strad instruments thought to still exist. That includes violins, violas, cellos, harps, mandolins, and guitars. And not all 650 are playable. Some of these are damaged beyond repair and some are only partial remains. Many of the 650 are thought to still exist but current ownership and/or location is unknown. There are about 200 known Antonio Stradivari violins who's ownership, location, and ability to be played are known. One is in totally pristine condition and is said to have never been played. And for every real Strad out there, there are probably dozens of fakes.

There isn't an existing Strad that hasn't been reworked over the centuries, the neck, the tail block, the neck block, the angle of the necks, how the neck was attached to the violin, the top and back plates, the bass bar, the bridges, have all been modified, even the pitch/tension placed upon the strings and thus the stresses placed upon the instrument's fabric, have all changed since Stradivari's day. If most, if not all the instruments has been modified over the centuries, can any of Stradivari's existing instruments be attributed to him, at what point do they cease to be the product of his hand/workshop? All of the old 'master' makers' works have been knocked about, and altered over the years, it wasn't just Stradivari's work that augmented to suit new musical styles, theories or fashions of the day - after an instrument leaves your workshop, you don't have a say, as to how it is treated or who can work on it, you just have to cross your fingers and hope for the best.

A special on educational TV some years ago pointed to maple found sunken in a river that had been used as a logging flume.  The logs sank due to just a little bit of density issues.  The wood, once sunk, stayed underwater for years but didn't decay.  Instead, the water soaked the wood and allowed for mineral exchange.  Some divers were searching the river for "found wood" and in each case that they found a sunken maple, they brought it to a local instrument maker.  At least some fraction of those logs had the kind of internal structure that the instrument makers wanted because they would buy the whole log to make guitars, violins, violas, etc.  Perhaps one in eight logs would be taken for instruments.  The rest went to furniture makers.  From what I recall (and this was 40+ years ago) the violins made from this long-soaked wood were very close in sound to Strads.

It's clear how they were made, the secret: Magic.

I participated in a blind sound comparison between cellos when I was at University (probably 1991). It was for students of the music program to learn the standard terminology for describing the 'sound' of instruments. The same cellist played the same two minute excerpt on ten different cellos. The cellist was behind something like six very thin, opaque curtains so sound wasn't overly affected, but the instruments were obscured. We were given a list of terms and were told rank them for each instrument. We weren't ask for preference or to identify the maker. We were simply meant to apply typical terms to the character of the sound produced.

When all of the instruments were played, Our rankings were put on a giant chart to see if how different people perceived sounds and applied terms. An eleventh column was included that was the cellists rankings.

I vividly remember that all eleven participants gave cello number 5 the same 1st ranking, "Dramatic." Number 5 was the Servais Stradivarius owned by the Smithsonian. We may not have been able to identify it as a Stradivarius (because we didn't know) but every person there chose the same words to describe it. It was truly dramatic.

I saw an article recently that talked about not the growth of the wood, but the sourcing. Basically, Stradivarius had second pickings on wood that had been sent downriver and subject to prolonged soaking and light infestation which created wood with unique, and unplanned, properties. Coupled with the even growth grain theory, it might indicate that he was a master who happened to have all the local variables fall into place during a specific historical period, some of them outside of his control.

I think I agree with the final conclusion.  You pay a lot of money to hear a special instrument, you relax and enjoy the sound.  You pay money to hear a player, you listen to his playing.  Both may be relaxing, but the goal is different.  You listen to the sound, you excuse the player.  You listen to the player, the quality of the sound is secondary.

But the bridge is  fastened to the body; it i simply held in place by the tension of the strings. If you loosen all the strings, the bridge will simply fall off. And also, the nut does  transmit sound to the body; it simply defines one end (the other being the bridge) of the vibrating portion of the string. The nut is not even located on the body, but at the top end of the neck, many inches away from the body.

In Finland they have come up with a method where they treat wood with steam. Original the idea was to make the wood more stable for various constructions and less effected by changing humidity and temperatures. By coincidence a luthier teacher saw how the wood looked through a microscope and thought it resembled the wood seen in strats. A lot of the impurities had vanished due to this treatments and the wood looks like it has been stored for 50 years. Ruokangas guitars are mad with wood treated this way . It might be that Stradivarius used a similar method when he made his instruments. An other factor can be that he used wood from trees that grew near to waterfalls. I heard a story about a Norwegian violin maker that was accused of washing his violins with human blood because they sounded different than other violins. Due to superstition at the time many of these instruments were burned because of this rumor. Some people even thought the instruments were possessed by the Devil.
The simple explanation was that he used trees that grew next to waterfalls. Apparently this ionize the wood and gives instruments made of them a different sound.

Another thing is that while we have a lot of new instruments that can't hold a candle to a Strad, most of them will be gone in the next century or so. A bad cheap fiddle will be bought by a poor student, live on a shelf without a case, will get dropped several times, then superglued back together, then it will be given to a homeless person, played in the rain, stolen, pawned, bought by a yuppie mom, painted white, hung on a wall for a year, and finally thrown away in its 10th year of existence. A decent violin will be bought by a professional or a serious hobbyist, live in a case, receive regular maintenance and repairs needed from the huge amount of wear and tear, then it will be resold to a serious hobbyist when too visibly worn, then inherited and resold to another, then one day it will lose structural integrity from wear and tear or someone will  break it beyond repair in a smoky bar after about 50 years of use. A great violin will be bought by a professional, live a happy life as a cherished tool of the trade, then be resold to another pro that will have it modified; then another pro will have it modified some more; and if it survives this without the modifications going wrong, one day another pro will decide it's a historical instrument and should be treated as such, won't play it as often and make sure it stays in the same condition for decades, then after their death it will be sold to a collector. A luxury violin will be bought by a rich non-player, kept in a display case or a safe, and loaned to professional players, and will live forever unless destroyed in a fire or something.

All of the lead up sounded very much like the kind of thing that's pretty common in other fields, like sommeliers enjoying what they believe to be expensive vintage wine even if it is actually dirt cheap modern wine put in an old bottle, or fans of pate actually being incapable of distinguishing it from wet dog food if presented on a nice plate.  It's called 'essentialism.'  Humans have an innate belief, very low level, that objects somehow have their history attached to them.  It's false, of course, and is nonsense, but it is inescapable.  Some might think people are lying to themselves when they say they enjoyed the vintage wine more than the cheap when it is revealed their bottles had been switched... but we've proven that is not what's going on.  The knowledge and expectation are what determine how our brain responds to stimulus, not the thing we are perceiving.

I've sifted through the comments and a picture emerges that might explain the high esteem placed on Stradivarius violins.
..
Mentioned in the video was the unique spruce wood grown through an intense volcanic activity ( perhaps the reason for the aluminum & copper traces found in the wood?)
This would give the wood the tight grain. Also mentioned in the comments., was the fact the wood may have been stored for 30 years again making the wood unique and very expensive.
Also mentioned (by a music teacher) was the fact Strad wood has small holes called "stoma" this would allow the wood to breath. (Yes possibly anecdotal).
..
It also appears Strads were modified and repaired during their lifetime and thus changing the instruments characteristics.
Some had the necks strengthend to cope with the high notes of more contemporary music.
Then there is the bone glue used in construction, this glue may be a similar density to wood and thus the whole violin cabinet, so to speak, would behave as one complete unit rather than small pieces glued together.
..
There is also another interesting fact mentioned by (Bob D)
Instruments that are played regularly sound better than one placed in cabinets as an art piece.
Considering the ~ 300 years of use again this may give Strads a unique sound.
..
The truth is we have to go back to the beginning. Not quite Adam and Eve, but to the time when Strads were first built.
Due to the fact there were no amplifiers in the Strad period, he made his violins to project the sound higher and further, (perhaps the silvery notes mentioned)
This was unique to Strads at the time and thus it's reputation grew.
Today most Strads are played by the very best musicians so we'll always have the best possible sound from them.
In conclusion, in the beginning Strads did have an edge on the competition but today with modern violin construction techniques - there is a more level playing field the difference is more subtle.
So it wood appear to today's contemporary ears,
Strads unique sound may just be psychological due to the heritage of the instrument rather than any real tangible difference.
We can't make a Stradivari violin because we are not the great-great-great-great-whatever grandchildren of the man. We can certainly make violins that are just as good, if not better.

One important thing to remember is that Stradivarius did not make Stradivarius violins. The instrumnets that came out of his workshop were very, very different from how they are today. Not only have they changed through aging, there was also a very lucrative business "upgrading" ancient violins during the 19th and early 20th century. It was common practice, especially by the two big Chicago dealers, Lewis & Son and Lyon & Healy, to thin down the wood of the top and bottom to increase the volume and drastically alter the tone of the instruments.

Just a bit of clarification on the frequencies of vibration.

No. They are not called “harmonics”. Harmonics are a result of electronic amplification.

Yes, Guitar players get this wrong, too (sorry, guys, you, too have been calling it the wrong thing).

They are called “partial vibrations” or “partials” for short. Partials can be harmonic OR inharmonic in nature. A string under tension will produce multiple vibrations which not only create the overall tonal structure of the note you hear but that’s how the musical scale was discovered. Problem is, the tones of the string under tension (and the piano soundboard and the violin woods) are not mathematical multiples of the fundamental like the overtone or the harmonic.

Woodwind and vocal instruments produce “overtones” which are similar but not the same as “partials” or “harmonics”. They are mathematical multiples of the fundamental tone. But “harmonics” are more like overtones than they are partials.

An electric organ produces “harmonics”. A pipe organ produces “overtones”.

A guitar string produces “partial vibrations”though the low tension of the string produces vibrations very close to mathematical multiples of the fundamental. But the fact that they are not “harmonic” is easily demonstrated by the reality that you have to retune the bridge saddles if you change string gauges. An acoustic guitar which doesn’t have a tuneable bridge will be more difficult to play in tune

When you play it through an amplifier, especially with distortion, you get “harmonics”.

This video missed a lot of important technical points. Like how the horsehair bow along the strings naturally makes a sawtooth wave, giving the violin's characteristic basic mix of harmonics. Like how the sound post, beneath one foot of the bridge, turns the sideways motion of the strings into an up and down motion that can actually get to the violin body. Which, of course, acts like a transformer in matching the impedance of the strings to that of the air so that a violin is loud enough to be heard.

Strads are a big deal and people can't tell them from modern instruments because he accidentally made instruments we prefer now. When he started there was no such thing as a symphony hall and his instruments weren't especially popular for a very long time. Our modern instruments arent made to sound like strads necessarily, it's just that some of his instruments happened to be made with a sound we'd come to appreciate for our tastes and purposes. They also happened to be amenable to modernization and that was comepletely by mistake. The necks were changed to higher angles to be louder and metal strings replaced gut.

Part of Strad's accomplishment was his adaptation of the materials to the manufacturing process. Another was his experimentation over the years to try to suit his customer base or to evolve the instrument. He wasn't supernatural. There are surviving strads that are turds and are considerably less valuable than you'd think because they neither sound great nor represent excellence in craftsmanship or a historical development. Some are less valuable because they don't sound like what we want according to our perception of what a violin is supposed to be.

Getting an accurate picture on this issue requires a deep dive. If you skim the surface, as done here, you end up taking at face value research papers that are problematic and sensationalist, and you miss instances of proposals that have later been demonstrated to be false (the effects of the Maunder Minimum, for instance). You also fail to get context for things like the double-blind listening tests, which don't account both for what happens when a player gets to know an instrument and learns to make use of its better qualities, or for the question of how sophisticated the audience's discrimination of violin tone is.

In the end this show, like science itself in the way it currently works in our culture, has served up a hodgepodge of inadequately vetted "answers", many of which fail even to properly frame the questions, thus perpetuating the flow through our culture of a lot of half-baked ideas about violins.

But don't mistake me--I just described, not 'the' problem, but one of many symptoms of our culture's mishandling of reasoning and information. Even the self-appointed promoters of knowledge are guilty.

Instrument making is a high level of skill mixed with equal parts of witchcraft. Why can a cheap guitar sound and play like some of the best guitars? Slight variations in the wood, a slight difference in the thickness of the parts, a variation in the placement of the bracing. So many subtle differences that can improve or destroy the sound characteristics of the instrument. Think of that cheap guitar, it was likely sanded on a thickness sander, the sandpaper was at the beginning, middle, or end of its life. The amount of pressure maybe different, the feed rate may have been changed. In addition, the parts of the guitar are married to other parts, perhaps the Muses smile down on one of ten thousand instruments and make it special. The skilled luthier controls many aspects of the process, but in the end some aspects of the instrument are beyond the control of the maker.
A guitar top starts at approximately 9/64ths of an inch. As the top is scraped and sanded the thickness is reduced to about 7/64ths. As the soundboard is thinned the maker taps the top and listens for the overtones. And at some point the top begins to resonate with rich tones as it nears its optimum thickness. The question is: How far do you go? There is a point of no return where the soundboard is stifled and there is nothing that can bring it back. Now think of that factory built guitar that the Muses smiled upon; it went through the thickness sander at the precise setting that produced the perfect resonance, more or less would have produced a lesser sound.

Cellist here. Much of the mystery is not really a mystery. Stradivari made thousands of instruments. The best-sounding ones survived, and only the best luthers work on them (they're usually highly modified by steel strings, different angles of the fingerboard, etc.). The soundpost, strings, bridge, tailpiece, and angles usually make more of a difference than the body. Some of his instruments are not so great sounding, even with the best luthier work. Some are too resonant on one frequency, creating nearly untamable wolf notes (resonance feedback that canceles the note intermittently). Yes, some of them are excellent, but one would naturally expect a few out of thousands to sound good. So yes, its mostly psychological. Again, the original instruments were built to use sheep gut strings, less sharply angled necks, shorter fingerboard, etc. They've become investments more than an instrumentalist's dream.

There's another point to this question. Modern violins mostly use steel or nylon strings, instead of gut strings. That, and the style of playing, make for very different sounds that gut strings. Also, as period instrument players and researchers have demonstrated, playing styles and even pitch varied a lot from modern practices (strongly influenced by the late 40s to 60s), which in their turn were influenced by the size of concert halls. Regardless, this discussion is of course academic. There's no magic behind Stradivarii violins, besides the magic of nostalgia and myth.

It may be a bit misleading to say that wood dries out as it ages. This is true to an extent, but after a couple years, in the dry season even a 2" thick slab will be as "dry" as it will ever get. Wood is hygroscopic, and doesn't continually lose moisture content as it ages, but rather gains and loses moisture depending on the relative humidity. Even very old wood will do this, which is why instruments should be stored in a controlled environment -- the constant gain and loss of moisture causes the wood to expand and contract, which can cause damage (splits, loss of adhesion at joints, etc.) if not mitigated.

I'm certain Stradivari had fully dried the wood before he began making any instrument with it. It may be that the metallic content came in from part of a kiln-drying process.

In the case of an instrument as incredible as a Strad, any damage of this type is essentially irreparable, because any material you add or remove will change how it vibrates. And most types of damage caused by this warping can't simply be forced out or reversed at all.

Often what people perceive as "drying out" is actually the lignin of the wood degrading due to UV exposure, or possibly early stages of dry rot, because these processes eliminate the wood's hygroscopic nature by destroying cell walls that act as selective (maybe not the right word here...just meaning that they gain/release moisture based on conditions) moisture barriers.

If any piece of woodwork is properly handled and kept, these issues can be greatly mitigated, which is why as many of these insturments still exist as they do.

There's no magic. Just reversed logic. Simply put, Strads were deemed the best violins, at the time, and that became the standard violin. As such, the "best sounding" violin is the one that sounds most like a Strad. Violas had no such standard established. That's why some violas sound bright and some are dark; some project deeply and others are more muted. Even the shapes are vastly different. While all violins are the same sizen and shape of a Strad, give or take a few millimeters. Violas, on the other hand, range from 15" all the way to 22" with drastically different shapes, contours, f-holes, etc. So a violin sounds like a Strad because someone decided that violins MUST sound like Strads.

Violin maker here--this video is legit. I've tried to answer this question more times than I can count, and Hank (and the rest of the team) hits the nail on the head in every way. Stradivarius violins are special, but it's not because Strad was some magician or saint. It was a combination of incredible craftsmanship on his end and super effective marketing by violin dealers throughout the years--starting with Vuillaume in Paris circa 1855, and only growing in intensity since then.

The historical facts around violins from this time period are mostly fuzzy and romanticized and I think that the violin world almost prefers it that way. If we knew everything about Strad, all of the mysteries solved and documented, then the very human experience of wonder and awe for these near-mythical objects would evaporate. I've heard Strads, Guarneris, and Amatis in person, both close up and in concert. I've stared at them for hours through glass and even held a few in my (washed, dried, and trembling) hands. The legendary status of these instruments creates almost a sanctified atmosphere that you simply can't replicate with modern instruments. The story impacts the experience.

The famous Norwegian violinist Arve Tellefsen bought his Guarnerius for 1 million Norwegian kroner (NOK). He did primarily buy the Guarnerius for his work and spent 20 years for paying his masterpiece. Even he never intended to buy his violin as an investment piece it really was.

In 2018 at age 81 he sold the Guarnerius for 84 million NOK to an undisclosed buyer and still have rights to play it for the rest of his life. With so many parts on a piano, there's a lot more room for difference than with a violin.

@1:57 you make the assertion that the nut is attached to the body. This is incorrect. The nut is simply a slight protuberance carved at the top of the fingerboard of the violin. It has small slots cut into to which seats the strings so they don't slip back and forth. The neck and the body are different components. You also claim that the sound is transmitted to the body via the nut and the bridge. This, again, is incorrect. The sound waves from the strings are transmitted to the body through the bridge only, which is not attached to the body, but is held in place by only the string tension.The purpose of the nut is simply to raise the strings slightly above the fingerboard. This makes it possible to use fingers the strings to produce different pitches
.

One part of the Strad's mystique would go away if people were aware that not a single fiddle survived unmodified from that time. The sound that violinists wanted from their instruments changed - due to fashion, and due to the technology available to other instruments. I have had the good fortune to play two Strads, neither of which I owned, but which I got to play for a couple of weeks on loan. There are several things that I wish to say about them. First off, neither was the best violin I've ever played, even though one was one of the top 25 Strads. Further, there are some Strads which really aren't that good by anyone's standards. If you have one of those, you own it because of the name, not because it is a really fine instrument.
Another thing one should know about the Strads are that all of them have been modified from the way Antonio Stradivari made them. When he was building violins the neck and fingerboard were shorter, the pitch standard was lower, the angle of the fingerboard was shallower, and the sound which the players of the time were trying for was entirely different. At the time of their making they were not considered to be all that good. Indeed the instruments of the man who taught him how to make violins, Nicolo Amati, were considered to be far superior. Even to this day there are people (myself included) who find the Amati instruments to be better. Another player of the time who made instruments which surpassed the instruments of Stradivari was Giuseppe Guarneri (aka Guarneri del Jesu). I am actually a violist who occasionally played violin if needed, and one of the two instruments I played professionally was a Guarneir del Jesu viola which was far superior to any Strad I ever laid hands on. It was also an instrument which had managed to remained unaltered since it was made(the other instrument I played was a modern copy of a 17th century instrument, and was made by a very talented modern luthier name Rolland Ross) .
I understand why the Strads are so highly considered. They produce a very bright sound, which is highly sought after in the modern orchestra. It is a sound however, which was not sought after until the mid 19th century. Further, you really have to struggle with the instrument in passages where a soft, quiet, delicate sound is required. It's a great instrument for solo concerto work on pieces written post 1800, but it is definitely the wrong instrument even when converted back to it's original dimensions, for music of the 18th century and earlier. In the opinion of many artists who try to recreate historically informed performances it is also not the instrument of first choice, even in a solo role.
Because of this, one has to wonder if it was the craftsmanship of Antonio Stradivari which make the instruments good, or if it is more a matter of lucky happenstance. I believe it is the latter, and that modern builders would be better served rather than trying to "unlock" the "mystery" of the Strad, to focus instead on making the best instruments they can without it being a copy of anything, and indeed, that's what the best luthiers today are doing. A lot about how an instrument sounds has to do with how well broken in it was, and how well it was maintained over the years. It's well known by professional players that a violin or viola which is left unplayed for a long period of time will loose it's voice, and I'm left to wonder if maybe some of the lower tier Strads may have suffered a fate of going for a long while unplayed.
To sum up, having an authentic Strad does not mean you have one of the best instruments out there, and even if you do have one of the best Strads, it is probably a waste of time trying to build an instrument which sounds the same as a Strad, because in time it will sound entirely different than what it sounded like originally, because even the Strads themselves do not sound like they did originally. Nothing will affect the sound of an instrument like the hundreds of years of daily playing does, and there is no way to hurry that process along. The bottom line is that the "Stradivarius sound" is not necessarily the best sound. The best sound is largely a myth, and the quality of sound you get out of the best violins has much more to do with the ability of the performer than it does with the instrument itself. It does have name recognition, and for that reason it is performer bling. But the secret amongst professionals is that there are other instruments available which will serve you just as well, if not better.
...and then there's the bow. But that's a whole other story for a whole other time.

I just want to point out that the test has a flaw that needs to be addressed. That is, the reputation of the Stradivarius violins came from 400 years ago but they were tested against MODERN violins. This, like the sommelier taste tests, ignores the simple fact that nearly everything improves over time, and that the direction of improvements in the realm of arts will tend to head towards closing with the golden standard. Stradivarius violins can't be differentiated from modern violins because modern violins have gone through 400 years of evolution to get closer and closer to the golden standard set by Stradivarius. Similarly, wine production improvements in the past 60 years or so have tended towards replicating the taste and quality of the expensive wines in the past, to the point that all wines today are pretty much the same. But ask a sommelier to compare an expensive wine from before this wine revolution to its peers and they would quickly identify the expensive one. In fact, you don't even need sommeliers. Turns out regular people could too. The wines WERE different then, the gap is just gone now. To see whether Strads are actually unique they should be compared to the violins that people had 400 years ago. The results might be surprising.

The takeaway, however, is still that Strads today are priced only on their legacy and not on their real qualities, just like how sommeliers are of somewhat questionable utility and expensive wines are a scam in the world of modern wines. No violinist objectively needs a Stradivarius violin today.

1. Stradivari was ILLITERATE. 👀❗️ He never wrote because he couldn’t read. 🤷‍♂️ (some of his makers stickers (inside the instrument) he even spelled his own name wrong.)
2. He had thickness scales, but not for symmetry. He did it for taper.
3. Early in his career, he got a lot of his lumber from SCRAPS by the doc. While Guineri was rich, Stradivari came from a poor family (his father was a relief carver). He actually used pine, cedar and oak on some of his instruments.
4. Stradivari had bad eyes and amazing ears. Thanks to his father’s job, he also was a master at sharpening blades, so his tools carved easily instead of stressing the wood from slightly dull blades (MAKES A HUGE DIFFERENCE).
5. His 1st 2 instruments were both 10 string guitars. Inspired by seeing them at a doc being played by a Spanish sailor, the instrument was SHUNNED in Italia, and his mentor SMASHED both of them.
6. He didn’t make just violins. He made cellos, violas, double bass, viola da gamba (but those are all gone forever). He even got commissioned to make instruments fir entire orchestras (by royalties).
7. He didn’t own anything to read because HE COULDN’T READ.🤷‍♂️ But he was friends with his neighbors and learned a lot about how (for example) acidic fruit blackens carbon steel.🤔 This got him into experimenting with how certain plants stain or effect woods. Fir example, broccoli was high in IRON (so was moss). Plants like blueberries, black pepper and basil. (Don’t play with your food!👊)
8. Not only could he not read, he also couldn’t count.🤦‍♂️ He used calipers to measure things (like binding one piece flush to another piece), but he never wrote it down!🤦‍♂️ He literally didn’t know!
9. By working by ear instead of making them within certain measurements, Stradivarius instruments came in various subtle differences in measurements. It was never about them all being the same sizes and shapes. It was always THE SOUND.
10. Taking a cue from Michelangelo (the stone statue carver), Antonio would stare at a piece of wood, examine it until he decided what it would be good for. A LOT of his instruments wood grains are… well… um… UGLY. They’re boring!🤷‍♂️ His competition would by the most beautiful, curly maple, burl woods with exotic grains. They’d take these pieces they bought for beauty and carve them until they got a decent tone. Antonio… He’d take that ugly wood he he chose for (whatever instrument he thought a piece was good for) and pull what was in his head right out of the plank.

So while everyone were making pretty instruments and trying to make them sound as good as they looked, Stradivari was making beautiful SOUNDING instruments, and trying to make them LOOK as good as they SOUNDED.
(conclusion) FORM FOLLOWS FUNCTION.
And that’s Stradivari. 👏

So the upshot is that esteeming an object because it has monetary value is specious. Perhaps we should just value things and people for what they do, not for some arbitrary and imposed quality that serves only avarice.

I have an antique violin made circa 1780. It's definitely no Strad, and there are other that are much MUCH more expensive and 'better' ones out there, but I LOVE my violin and our sound is special and beautiful.

What many don't realise is that the violin 'learns' how to resonate with each player over time. The process needs a reasonably decent technique and takes place over weeks or months, but when it opens up you can feel and hear a definite shift. It's almost spiritual! Like a golden shaft of sunlight in a dark room, or unlocking a secret bonus level and skillset in a game. We've been together for 25 years now - as I improve WE improve.

I've had a chance to play an Armati and a high-end replica of a Strad for about 3 minutes each - I was so intimidated I couldn't enjoy it, and played like I couldn't even hold the thing! 😂

I'm not sure if a study with musicians picking up different instruments to play, rather than spending time to unlock that wider resonance, really shows the instruments at their best. But I don't really care! Any well made violin played by a reasonable musician with love, character and skill is as precious as a rare diamond in my eyes.

Besides lateral discussions, just a bit more of context about the uniqueness of their construction; The Stradivari were a family of luthiers and violin makers that worked, experimented and pass their craftwork, knowledge, tools and materials through generations. One other of the main problems we have today to reproduce same construction materials is the time needed to curate and age lacquers and varnishes as it was at the Stradivari workshop. Even if we handle to figure out the exact recipes to make those lacquers and varnishes, we'll have to wait in some cases as long as a couple hundred years before they could be applied, and then wait a couple of hundred more until musical instrument is mature.

Blind listening tests with professional players listening to other professional players and comparing antique violins and very good modern violins typically find that preference is essentially random. There is no inherent bias toward the old masters’ instruments… even among people who admit they have a personal preference. Basically, in the research I’ve looked at, it’s really hard to tell what violin you’re hearing if it’s a good quality pro instrument and if the player knows what they’re doing. I’ve not probably encountered every study on this… but in at least some tests this seems to be the case. Nobody can actually reliably tell what violin they’re hearing. There is a scientifically identifiable difference in the old vs new, but not one that is readily apparent to even a trained listener.

FYI: Having analysed the sonic characteristics of the violin (the "Strad' among them) the unique quality of the violin sound is difficult to "hear", unless one is blessed with a rare "ear". To wit: If one plays middle C, the C above middle C has twice the amplitude of the played note, with a resultant upward "energy shift" of Harmonic partials. The ear "hears" the played note (dominant) but it is "colored" by the boosted energy of the accessory (+) octave. It is perceptual "dissonance" which provokes a "visceral" response, which can, in some instances, provoke the emotional response unique to the instrument. The sonic profile unique to any instrument is established in the energy balance of harmonic partials within the sound "envelope". In true sound synthesis (as opposed to electronically SIMULATED) a guitar can be "glissed" (shifted) to sound like a trumpet by adjusting the balance of odd and even-numbered partials and their relative energy, via the rule of sums and differences.
The Strad (at least the two that were tested) has a unique energy balance in the even-numbered partials (esthetically pleasing) and an energy "boost" on the partials bass end, two octaves below the played note. Although an "autopsy" of the Strads tested was strictly precluded, trace mineral salts (alumina among them) in the wood, (we believed) was the result of "pickling" prior to seasoning (drying) the blank. These combined elements would have required a slow process, commenced several years before the blank could be shaped, primarily by scraping... not to mention the choice of "China" lacquer: made from the carapace of the lacquer beetle. Of note: we did not rely solely on electronic devices to test the sonic qualities of the Strad, but enlisted the abilities of a concert violinist, who could detect a tonic variance (off-tune) of 1/8 of a partial in a played note. She was able to identify the Strad every time.
