I feel like people tend to forget a few important facts about Strads -- for one, exactly zero Strads are in the same condition or shape they were when they were first created. All of them have been through series of repairs and patches and have been serviced by luthiers over the centuries. That's not even counting how the wood itself has aged. Second, the design of the bridge -- which is critically important to how the instrument sounds -- that Stradivari used is not really the one used on any violin, including Stradivarius instruments, today. The modern violin/viola bridge is actually Guarneri's design and what Stradivari used bears more resemblance to a modern cello bridge. That means it's an absolute certainty that they sounded quite different in the 1600s than they do today even apart from all the servicing and age. Thirdly, Stradivari experimented with loads of designs. His early instruments were much closer to the Amati designs, but they changed over the years and he tried experiments with different shapes and designs without cornices.

The notion that Stradivari never wrote down his "process" is not entirely correct. He left behind loads of writings and diagrams and drawings. It's just that he felt that the design and shape of the instrument and the design of the bridge was the most important thing. If there was any process of treating the wood that he used but didn't write down, it would be because it wasn't new or at least he didn't personally invent it. Before Strads and Guarneris, Amatis and Stainer violins were the prized ones. Both Bach and Mozart themselves had Stainer violins. They lost popularity when orchestras and venues got bigger and there was a need for soloists to have instruments that projected more with more power.

Also, I'm a little curious about the mention of Guarneri being "just as old", but with no mention of how Guarneri del Gesu violins compare. In spite of the fact that Stradivarius carries the bigger name, actual violinists tend to view this comparison as a toss-up and down to personal preference. I happen to be one of those who prefers the sound of del Gesu violins to that of Stradivarius (and both makers' violins will sell for 8 figure prices), but that is a matter of personal taste. Guarneri's tend to be a bit more resonant in the lower harmonics and some of that just comes down to size -- Guarneri often toyed with taller ribs and broader upper bouts.

I feel like the most important thing that people miss is that even the "old masters" were willing to mess with the design of the instrument. There's actually a lot of room to play with the design of a violin/viola and still have something that is really good. We look back at the Strads and try to say "let's try to copy this," without ever asking the question "*why* did he do that?". People are too buried in tradition and this idea that Stradivari already perfected the bowed string instrument, and there is nothing more to do. When in reality, he was willing to try new things, as was Guarneri... when nobody does that today, you end up stuck in a rut of trying to go backwards instead of forward. If you look at any of the violins made by Julius Zoller, for instance, you'd find something that looks utterly alien with its sound holes in the ribs and sympathetic string through the center of the bridge and all sorts of things that the likes of TwoSet would call sacrilegious... and yet, for that, it produces a sound that sounds quite astonishingly mature and by no means out of place in any orchestra. It's not a million-dollar instrument, but it would easily stand middle of the pack in a field of modern professional-grade instruments.

In regards to violins and wine, here is my take on it. Strads are undoubtedly exceptional violins and had construction techniques that not only helped make it better but also distinctive. These characteristics made them stand out from lower quality instruments so in time these characteristics become associated with fine quality, regardless of these characteristics inate contribution to quality. In modern times we have access to materials, technology, techniques, and capital to produce fine instruments in mass quantities and exceptional instruments in limited production.

Similarly for famous, expensive wines, none of them would be called bad wines, at worse you may say they are not good value. In blind tastings, experts are able to identify wines by comparing the wines characteristics to their mental database of the characteristics of wines from different years, vineyards and winemakers.

According to a report by The Brighter Side of News, a Texas A&M University scientist has co-authored new research confirming the unique sound quality produced by instruments created by renowned violin maker Antonio Stradivari as well as others. It’s the result of the instruments being treated with chemicals, several of which have now been identified for the first time.

After years of research, Joseph Nagyvary, a professor emeritus of biochemistry at Texas A&M, first proposed and proved the theory nearly 40 years ago. It was not so much the skill of making the instrument, but rather the chemicals used in the process that accounted for the unmatched sound of those created by Stradivari and others such as Guarneri del Gesu. The chemicals were used due to a worm infestation at the time.

Nagyvary’s findings at the time were verified in a review by the American Chemical Society, the world’s largest scientific organization, the report said.

Current findings by an international team led by Hwan-Ching Tai, professor of chemistry at National Taiwan University, have been published in Angewandte Chemie International Edition.

The findings of the research team show that the chemicals used to treat the wood used in the instruments were “borax, zinc, copper, and alum—along with lime water,” the news outlet reported.

Nagyvary noted the use of borax as a preservative goes back to the ancient Egyptians who used it in “mummification and later as an insecticide.” He added due to widespread worm infestations at the time, both Stradivari and Guarneri would have wanted to treat their violins to “prevent worms from eating away the wood.” Each would have his own “home-grown methods” for the wood’s treatment, in collaboration with “the local drugstore and druggist at the time.”

“This new study reveals that Stradivari and Guarneri had their own individual proprietary method of wood processing, to which they could have attributed a considerable significance,” Nagyvary said.
It’s reportedly possible they became aware the special salts they used for permeating the wood also imparted to it “some beneficial mechanical strength and acoustical advantages.” Therefore, the methods “were kept secret,” adding a “competitive advantage” over other instrument makers

According to documents found in the 90's, Stradivari did not have his lumber shipped cut. Full green trees. Because of this the trees were sent to a port. Not shipped over land like his competitors and not air dried like theirs. The trees were lashed to the side of a ship that had a constant and long route.
As the trees were green when they hit the sea water so they exchanged fluids. The sap being in water was thinned flowing from the tree quickly without cracking the tree from uneven drying. This occurs from air drying too fast. Sea water would flush out the sap leaving all the zillions of nifty chemicals from the sea behind. The process gave the cell structure great regularity packing them with the goodies from the sea. Making the cells firmer. Air drying is a process of desiccation. Causing shrinkage.
Mystery solved 3 decades ago.
The guy that figured it out patented the process and produced lumber for high end wood instruments. Who knows he may still be in business or bankrupt or dead? He was on an episode of Real People, How Did They Do That or equivalent.

This happens with everything in music too from vintage guitars, to drums to synthesizers. I'm a big synth fan and everyone is always fighting over digital hardware recreations of vintage analog synths, or software versions of vintage analog synths. Many people claim they can hear a 'harsh and digital sound' with the digital / software versions but when given a blind poll most results come up as 50/50% right/wrong, and then people blame it on streaming audio compression. My opinion: if you can't hear the difference streaming it online they might as well sound the same since everyone streams music nowadays. Plus non-musicians won't pick up on most of the details enthusiasts or pro's will notice.

So why buy analog or vintage synths? 1. the digital / software versions all sound the same and are based off of 1 particular unit typically, where as vintage versions of synths (or any instrument really) are going to have a character based on decades of aging. 2. in music how the artist feels actually matters. every piece of gear inspires its own writing style which can be amazing. Using the software version doesn't give the same tactile feel and using a modern recreation doesn't make you feel like you're using something special and rare. When you're turning emotions and feelings into a sound, your headspace matters a great deal in the writing / recording process. 3. some gear will change tuning based on temperature, even modern analog gear. Digital vintage instruments use older chips that cause unique aliasing or have a low bit depth, and the unique combination of these elements can really change the sound. This CAN be modeled in software in many cases but often its not, and most instruments don't have modern recreations or software versions. 4. its just cool to own something rare and special if you have the cash. Obviously Stradivari is one of the most extreme versions of this.

I would imagine when it comes to Stradivarius violins many of these things apply. Special combinations of wood, lots of aging, the inspiration a performer has when playing something so rare and special. Even if in a blind test people don't choose it as the 'better' violin, it's relatively likely that due to these qualities it at least sounds unique. An interesting test would be to get 4 high-end modern violins from different makes / models and 1 Stradivari violin and do a double blind test to have the listeners point out the most unique instrument.

The Philadelphia Orchestra (once renowned for the sound of their string section) used to audition prospective string players behind a screen.  This was the practice during the era of Stokowski and Ormandy and a great part of their criteria for selection was the sound of the instrument they were hearing.   Anyone who had heard that string section live would tell you that the sound they made was incredibly sensuous and lush. Whether that sound was created by the instruments or the players or both was irrelevant when you heard it.  It was real, not imagined.  If you hear a Strad and it sounds extraordinary, it matters little as to why it does.  "Beauty is in the eye of the beholder."

Whoa there. Don't just mention Guarneri with only a passing remark that he was a contemporary. Truth be told the Guarneri del Gesu violins are held by many to be better than Strads. The two greatest violinists of all time, Heifetz and Paganini, owned multiples of both Strads and Guarneri's and both preferred the latter. For my money, the two greatest sounding violins of all time are the  ex-Pagaini "Il Canone" and the ex-Vieuxtemps that Heifetz played in the final years of his career. Utterly amazing!  Neither is privately owned (Paganini donated his violin to his home town of Genoa upon his death and deserving violinists are still allowed to play it; upon Hefetz's death, the violin was gifted to an association and is lent to the concert master of the San Francisco Symphony). If either ever came up for sale, who knows what price they would command. I would expect it would surpass the current record which is north of 30 million dollars. I am myself a classically trained violinist and have had the enormous honour of playing a Strad and a Guarneri. The Strad (at the time) was worth about 8 million dollars. The Guarneri had gone through some major repairs and was worth in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, in comparison. Even knowing the price gap, I would take that Guarneri every day of the week.  One final thought, Stradivari worked as a violin maker for many, many decades. Not every instrument that left his shop was of equal quality. Indeed, for instruments from his later period, it is not known how involved he was personally in the instrument's construction; it may be as much a product of a student or apprentice as of Stradivari himself. I have spoken to my luthier about Strads on a few occasions. He has mentioned working on a few Strads that were kind of clunkers. They weren't all top notch.

The reason the process wasn't written down is because most of the wood used to make them was stolen. He would cutting wood from the pylons under the docks in Venice. The sewage mixed with the water under the homes of the people of Venice left little air pockets that give the wood it's character. Due to the process being organic it isn't really possible to scientifically reproduce plus no one would really know what forests the wood for those pylons came from,, but they would know at least the type of wood which gives us a clue.

When his sons took over the business they could no longer steal this wood without collapsing buildings so they followed a formula that was based on the original and then their children created their own company "The Sons of Stradivarius" which are excellent violins but not the same.

We still see this phenomenon play out today…it’s called “hype”. Did Antonio make some of the best violins ever produced? Yes. Are they “better” than modern instruments? Objectively, no. We’ve had hundreds of years worth of industrial evolution since then. Stradivari came along very early in the game…he was among the first internationally notable luthiers to set up shop shortly after the violin took its modern form. If aliens landed, you showed them a strad then showed them a modern violin, they would point to the modern instrument while making beeping, clicky noises. But it’s the same in the guitar world (my specialty). Strats and Les Pauls from the 50s command prices that are obscene beyond belief. But people tell stories, talk about “special wood”, “hand built” this and that when proclaiming their superiority. I own several vintage instruments, including a 1954 Fender. It’s awesome! But is it better than a modern instrument (with more reliable tuners, tighter tolerances and quiet, potted pickups)? No, it’s not…its value is in its heritage. That’s the true nature of valuable, vintage instruments.

Study found that experts cannot distinguish a Stradivari from a group, but always blindly prefer the new violin. There's no stradivari sound.  Why you "can't make another stradivari" is simply because it was made from a special wood.

I read a study once of the finish used on the Strads. The result was that it continued everything from bees wax to cow's urine. Famously, there is a (probably apocryphal) story about someone holding a Strad only to realize that they'd made a finger print in the finish. 20 minutes later, the finger print was gone, implying that the finish on these hundreds of years old fiddles never totally sets.
In the world of banjos, the Gibson Mastertones made before WWII are deemed to be the "Strads" of the banjo world. Countless studies have been made on these instruments. I've played a few and can only conclude that excellence is largely in the ear of the beholder. What sounds and plays great to me, is not going to get the same response from other pickers. I've played modern banjos a fraction of the price that i thought played and sounded as good if not better. Because 5 string banjos were very rare before the war (the banjo craze had consisted of 4 string tenors largely) a lot of the value of these banjos is simply that there aren't many of them. The very best examples have been valued at upwards of 150,000. A lot for a banjo.

In addition to the woods used, Stradavari used a varnish that he made himself, which may be the "secret sauce" that shows up (although I'm not really sure where he would have gotten the aluminium from). The types of wood used can make a difference of thousands of dollars in the price of an instrument, with the price increasing as the wood gets harder and more dense. Most high-end oboes and clarinets use grenedilla  wood. In some cases, woods that were used in the past are no longer available, either because the forests are gone or are protected. In some cases, there are existing instruments that are 100+ years old that are still played and are highly desired by professionals.

I have a Strad story.

I was rehearsing with my choir at one of our choir members’ house. It was a regular rehearsal until out of nowhere, the grandpa of the choir member (the one who offered to rehearse at his house) told me that he owns a valuable instrument.

It was so valuable that the day he passes away, his offsprings will fight in court to obtain this instrument.

I was intrigued of the instrument that the elderly gentleman possessed and asked what was it. He stated that it is a Strad.

I couldn’t believe it and asked if I could see his “Strad”. He obliged and brought his instrument to show everybody.

It was an old violin with a replaced bridge. I asked if I could see the label inside the violin. (To see if it’s the real deal)

I couldn’t believe it. I was holding a Strad!

I asked how he obtain such instrument.
He responds that he bought the violin from a dealer from a music shop in Mexico. The dealer sold the instrument for cheap price, not knowing what he had.

He also stated that the way he found out he has the Strad was from a violin maintenance personnel who told him that he has a very coveted violin.

I am pretty sure the instrument had to be inspected for legal reasons.

Piano strings are not single strings,, each felt hammer strikes two or three strings. They are not tuned to exactly the same frequency.
I have been privileged in my lifetime in the music I have both listened to and sung. And even more especially by the instruments and instrumentalists I have known. First,, not all Stradivari are alike,, some I would even go so far to say are quite plain in their sound. When a front of spruce is to me mated with a back of maple, firstly they have lain on shelves drying for as long as a decade,, and when chosen to match each other they are sounded,, tapped with a metal hammer,, often brass and each flitch, block of wood will have a pitch or tone unique to that block. To chose which blocks will spend their lives together, the blocks are sounded and then paired BECAUSE their native pitch is something just less than half a tone apart. The front and the back begin not with a same tone but with separate pitch to complement each other.

There are violins that when played well will bring you to tears the sound so rich and lovely. This is not an exaggeration. And,,, I have also heard the sound of a one day old violin,, played by an elementary school music teacher,, her husband being a violin maker,, in an elementary school auditorium,, so sweet,. clear, perfect,, the tears ran freely down my face.

Perhaps the minerals in the maple could’ve been deposited with sand. Yes, sanding gets its name from using sand on wood. Traditional woodworking planes and scrapers are far too sharp and high grit to take some varnishes. High grit iron blades can even produce water-repellant surfaces on wood (temporarily). This meant that craftsman of the past would apply finishes and stains with a slurry of sand to scratch the surface and give it “tooth” so the finish can stick. I have no doubt that the bizarre oils used in combination with sanding could leave behind traces of metal.
@SciShow "DAMPING", not "DAMPENING".  Reducing vibrations "DAMPS" the vibrations.  "DAMPENING" would make it wet.

First 1 want to say: 400+ years of musicians playing on these instruments and then having them still be in a condition to be played today can't be taken for granted.
The musician playing the instrument is important too because a good musician knows how to get the best out of their instrument.
I played the viola for 7 years.
Lessons and classes on music theory...
I loved it and planned to play professionally.
Then in 10th grade, while standing on a table, I fell and broke 3 of the fingers on my left hand.
The guy I was working with vomited when he saw the directions my fingers were in - if you want an idea of how badly they were broken.
I even had one of them rebroken in the hopes that it would heal better.
I kept playing after they healed until I got out of high-school but never got back the range of motion needed to play professionally.
Not that you need to "be" in the business to know about those fabulous violins.
They were the dream.

God I hate Stradivarius. The instruments are great, but his legacy is the worst thing to happen to violin making. Here we are, nearly 300 years later, and new violins are still judged by how Strad they are. Improve the sound if you can, but don't you DARE mess with the art style. And so now the market is flooded with thousands upon thousands of Strad clones, and if you want something else you can just suck it.

So it's the old "perceived quality makes you feel better" thing. It's the same thing in the visual arts world where people are convinced that buying more expensive brushes or drawing tablets makes them better.....or even gamers who think an RGB keyboard will improve their game. It's a confidence boost.
